text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new Dillinger
Escape Plan album one of us is the
killer The Dillinger Escape Plan is a
New Jersey lab rock outfit who since the
late 90s has been one of the most
interesting groups out there to meld
elements of hardcore and metal now
despite the band's very complex and type
playing heavy guitars they have pretty
much avoided many tags from the prog
metal or the gent direction and on the
new LP as well the band deflects those
labels mostly because of their post
hardcore influence which occasionally
pops up on these tracks and they're very
Mike Patton inspired chord progressions
and vocal experiments it's stuff like
this that has kept the band's music
pretty interesting over the years as
they have stayed devoted to their very
[ __ ] fast disorienting musical style
now on this new full-length LP The
Dillinger Escape Plan is just as
hard-hitting as ever matching up
difficult to pin down guitar riffs with
drums that are dizzying to say the least
thanks to Billy rhymer for those and the
band's frontman great but not only is he
an aggressive fierce vocalist but he is
very dynamic as well sometimes
channeling vocal ranges and Tambor's
that remind me of guys like Mike Patton
as well as Trent Reznor many of the
tracks on the selfie feature speedy riff
laden versus but slowed down almost
instantaneously as soon as the chorus
hits and soar melodically and not to
mention our incredibly catchy Dillinger
clearly displays the line separating a
melodic chorus from a Wimpy chorus and
they don't cross it not even once on
this LP as if it's easy even as they
present songs on here like the title
track which has a very ethereal intro
sort of has a a very moody tumbleweed
spaghetti-western kind of set up to it
and Greg comes through singing swapping
out his very fierce growls and head's
splitting screams for very passionate
falsettos and some really great singing
in his mid-range - they're just really
crushing chords on the hook - this song
[Music]
loving the melody on this track and at
the end of every measure I believe
that's the term I want to use the band
has a little bit of variation on the
riffs and the grooves just to bring just
a touch of newness freshness anymore it
keeps things interesting and also with
the chorus on this thing it is so sweet
and it's so catchy and I actually think
this track could do some radio play if
you're talking about you know a modern
metal hard rock station and nobody would
even flinch at being offended or this is
too loud or this is too aggressive a lot
like older bands like Faith No More who
clearly have at least a little bit of an
influence on this record The Dillinger
Escape Plan finds a perfect balance
between extremity and accessibility this
track is just really really easy to get
into even if you're not a huge metal fan
even if you're just a regular rock fan
however it doesn't really feel like the
band compromised their sound that much
to make this track there are other
tracks on here too which come off a
little mr. bungle esque as they switch
their drums and guitars from metal mode
to kind of jazzy lounge mode tracks like
nothing's funny which to me has one of
the most stellar hooks on this LP and
paranoia shields this track in
particular shows the band bringing in
some really nice background
instrumentation this is a move that the
band is no stranger to there have been
plenty of LPS in their back catalog that
have featured strings but strings don't
actually play at least a noticeable role
on this LP on this particular track
horns and epic huge background vocals
this track is one of the longer and more
multifaceted songs on this album I love
how much the band is able to throw at me
the listener and yet keep things pretty
cohesive the song cross burner is pretty
long and multifaceted as well to go back
to instrumentation the only moment we're
adding a little bit extra see if that
old was with the song magic that I held
you Dillinger works in what feels like a
little bit of glockenspiel on the track
however it melds with the heavy metal
guitars in the song horribly it feels as
if they had to mix it over the guitars
much louder than anything else actually
just to get it to read audibly against
the distortion
the banging drums now these very catchy
sweet straightforward and instrumentally
refined tracks or counterbalance very
nicely with tracks that are nothing but
earthquake like Furies of riffs and
drums they're bloody they're like the
song Prancer that opens the cell P up Oh
tons of shrill chords all over this
thing it's just a pummel session at the
listener and it's really one of the most
blazing openers I've heard on a metal
record this year I also love the chord
changes that come into play and the epic
melodic ascent the song makes toward the
end as well it's a nice second half at
this track presents also the syncopated
chords and vocals that are met with
skipping drums on the next track on this
LP when I lost my bet our masterfully
played that track and understanding
decay are more examples prime examples
of this band playing grooves that are so
odd and strange and yet they rock them
so fluidly to the point where yeah sure
they're technically proficient but the
listener has such a straight visceral
reaction to it you don't really need to
sit there and think about what the
groove is or how you should Bob your
head to it it just comes so naturally
with how they play it off showing that
The Dillinger Escape Plan is the band
for you if you're more into just being
rocked and having a reaction than just
simply flashy playing because certainly
they have that the only track on here
that really kind of left me cold and
still you know do you really have a lot
of momentum - it was the eighth track on
here which was relatively shortened to
me really felt like more of a riff idea
than a song and the closer on the end of
this album didn't really feel that
climactic in my opinion it was rough it
was wild but maybe I was waiting for a
bit of closure or something at the end
of this LP overall I have to say maybe
this is slightly a little bit Dillinger
Escape Plan by the numbers and it sort
of wears a lot of khatyn isms on its
sleeve still this is an incredibly
performed written and produced metal
record very solid and I would
I commend it to anybody who was looking
for some loud rock that is not only
accessible but has a little bit of an
edge to it has a strong element of
surprise and some interesting riffs I'm
feeling a light a decent eight on this
thing if you've given it a listen hey
what did you think what should i review
